title: The weak form of 'to'
description: In natural speech, the preposition 'to' reduces from /tuː/ to /tə/. This weak form is used in almost all unstressed positions.
exampleSentence: I need to go to the store.
exampleTranscription: I need tə go tə the store.
tips: The vowel becomes a quick schwa sound
Only stressed 'to' keeps the full /tuː/ sound
Listen for this in phrases like 'to the', 'to a', 'going to'

title: The weak form of 'for'
description: The preposition 'for' reduces from /fɔːr/ to /fər/ in unstressed positions. This is one of the most common weak forms.
tips: The vowel shortens to a schwa
Only emphatic 'for' keeps the full pronunciation

title: The weak form of 'of'
description: The preposition 'of' reduces from /ʌv/ to /əv/ or even just /ə/. The 'v' often disappears completely in fast speech.
tips: In fast speech, may sound like just 'uh'

title: The weak form of 'and'
description: The conjunction 'and' reduces from /ænd/ to /ənd/, /ən/, or even just /n/. This is extremely common in connected speech.
tips: Often reduced to just 'n' between words
Listen for it in 'rock and roll', 'come and go'

title: The weak form of 'the'
description: The article 'the' has two weak forms: /ðə/ before consonants and /ði/ before vowels. The full /ðiː/ is rare.
exampleSentence: The book is on the table.
exampleTranscription: Thə book is on thə table.

title: The weak form of 'a'
description: The article 'a' reduces from /eɪ/ to just /ə/ (schwa). This is the default pronunciation in natural speech.
tips: The full /eɪ/ is only used for emphasis
This is the most common weak form in English

title: The weak form of 'him'
description: The pronoun 'him' reduces from /hɪm/ to /ɪm/, dropping the 'h' sound completely in unstressed positions.
tips: Common after verbs: 'tell him', 'ask him', 'give him'

title: The weak form of 'her'
description: The pronoun 'her' reduces from /hɜːr/ to /ər/, dropping the 'h' sound. This is standard in connected speech.

title: The weak form of 'them'
description: The pronoun 'them' reduces from /ðem/ to /ðəm/ or /əm/, with the 'th' often weakening or disappearing.

title: The weak form of 'can'
description: The modal verb 'can' reduces from /kæn/ to /kən/ in positive sentences. Note: 'can't' always stays strong.
tips: This helps distinguish 'can' from 'can't' in speech

title: The weak form of 'was'
description: The verb 'was' reduces from /wʌz/ to /wəz/ in unstressed positions, with the vowel becoming a schwa.
tips: The vowel becomes a quick schwa
Only emphatic 'was' keeps the full sound

title: The weak form of 'were'
description: The verb 'were' reduces from /wɜːr/ to /wər/ in unstressed positions, similar to 'her' becoming 'er'.
